awd_titl_txt: Dynamical systems on nilmanifolds, ultrafilters, and polynomial multiple correlation sequences
awd_abstract_narration:
The problems and conjectures presented in this program can be viewed as far reaching extensions of classical recurrence results in dynamics. At the same time, these problems connect diverse areas of mathematics (such as ergodic theory, combinatorics, number theory, topological algebra) and contribute to each. The new problems considered in this proposal deal with interesting and promising new connections and reflect the entrance of novel methods and techniques in the picture. These include, in particular, the methods involving dynamical systems on nilmanifolds and methods utilizing the topological algebra in compactifications. The conjectures stated throughout this proposal are supported by the results obtained by the investigators and other workers in this vibrant area in recent years.

The polynomial Szemeredi theorem, the polynomial Hales-Jewett theorem, and various additional results obtained by the investigators in recent years served as an impetus for further developments in the theory of multiple recurrence. These developments provide better understanding of the phenomenon of multiple recurrence and bring new vistas of research to light.  The directions of study touched upon in this proposal reveal strong and mutually perpetuating connections between combinatorics, number theory and various aspects of recurrence and convergence in the theory of dynamical systems. The field of Ergodic Ramsey Theory, with its richness of problems and connections and diversity of techniques and methods, is a meeting point of several branches of modern mathematics and is an excellent medium for attracting undergraduates to mathematics and graduate students to an area of active research.

por.por_cntn:
The research performed by the principal investigators belongs to the mathematical area of dynamical systems with an emphasis on applications to and connections with combinatorics and number theory. A dynamical system is comprised of a state space and and the evolution rule which describes the time dependence of the positions of the points in the state space. Ergodic theory, a branch of dynamical systems, is mainly concerned with the study and applications of those dynamical systems which have invariant measure, that is, a way of assigning weights to different parts of the space which does not change with time. While the initial development of ergodic theory was motivated by problems of statistical physics and celestial mechanics, its modern applications include a wide variety of areas, including combinatorics and number theory. Mathematical topics and research directions which were considered and advanced by the principal investigators included:
* uniform distribution and polynomial recurrence in finite characteristics;
* ergodic theory of non-amenable semigroup actions;
* new forms and applications of the van der Corput difference theorem;
* recurrence properties of translations on nilmanifolds;
* fine properties of sets of  values of correlation function related to multiple recurrence;
* new polynomial and multidimensional extensions of classical partition results;
* interplay between notions of additive and multiplicative largeness;
* actions of the affine group and applications to Ramsey theory;
* normal sets in amenable groups;
* applications of multiplicative functions to Ergodic Ramsey Theory;
* the phenomenon of over- and under-independence in measure-preserving systems.

Results obtained by the principal investigators widely dessiminated via publications, web-postings and presentations at various forums.
